12234 stp->syserr = "lseek";
12235 stp->error_no = errno;
12236 return (int)cur;
12237 }
12238 copy_length = src_size - cur;
12239 }
12240 }
12241
12242 retry_sendfile:
12243# if SIZEOF_OFF_T > SIZEOF_SIZE_T
12244 /* we are limited by the 32-bit ssize_t return value on 32-bit */
12245 ss = (copy_length > (off_t)SSIZE_MAX) ? SSIZE_MAX : (ssize_t)copy_length;
12246# else
12247 ss = (ssize_t)copy_length;
12248# endif
12249 if (use_pread) {
12250 ss = simple_sendfile(stp->dst_fptr->fd, stp->src_fptr->fd, &src_offset, ss);
12251 }
12252 else {
12253 ss = simple_sendfile(stp->dst_fptr->fd, stp->src_fptr->fd, NULL, ss);
12254 }
12255 if (0 < ss) {
12256 stp->total += ss;
12257 copy_length -= ss;
12258 if (0 < copy_length) {
12259 goto retry_sendfile;
12260 }
12261 }
12262 if (ss < 0) {
12263 if (maygvl_copy_stream_continue_p(0, stp))
12264 goto retry_sendfile;
12265 switch (errno) {
12266 case EINVAL:
12267#ifdef ENOSYS
12268 case ENOSYS:
12269#endif
12270#ifdef EOPNOTSUP
12271 /* some RedHat kernels may return EOPNOTSUP on an NFS mount.
12272 see also: [Feature #16965] */
12273 case EOPNOTSUP:
12274#endif
12275 return 0;
12276 case EAGAIN:
12277#if EWOULDBLOCK != EAGAIN
12278 case EWOULDBLOCK:
12279#endif
12280 {
12281 int ret;
12282#ifndef __linux__
12283 /*
12284 * Linux requires stp->src_fptr->fd to be a mmap-able (regular) file,
12285 * select() reports regular files to always be "ready", so
12286 * there is no need to select() on it.
12287 * Other OSes may have the same limitation for sendfile() which
12288 * allow us to bypass maygvl_copy_stream_wait_read()...
12289 */
12290 ret = maygvl_copy_stream_wait_read(0, stp);
12291 if (ret < 0) return ret;
12292#endif
12293 ret = nogvl_copy_stream_wait_write(stp);
12294 if (ret < 0) return ret;
12295 }
12296 goto retry_sendfile;
12297 }
12298 stp->syserr = "sendfile";
12299 stp->error_no = errno;
12300 return (int)ss;
12301 }
12302 return 1;
12303}
12304#endif
12305
12306static ssize_t
12307maygvl_read(int has_gvl, rb_io_t *fptr, void *buf, size_t count)
12308{
12309 if (has_gvl)
12310 return rb_read_internal(fptr, buf, count);
12311 else
12312 return read(fptr->fd, buf, count);
12313}
12314
12315static ssize_t
12316maygvl_copy_stream_read(int has_gvl, struct copy_stream_struct *stp, char *buf, size_t len, off_t offset)
12317{
12318 ssize_t ss;
12319 retry_read:
12320 if (offset < (off_t)0) {
12321 ss = maygvl_read(has_gvl, stp->src_fptr, buf, len);
12322 }
12323 else {
12324#ifdef HAVE_PREAD
12325 ss = pread(stp->src_fptr->fd, buf, len, offset);
12326#else
12327 stp->notimp = "pread";
12328 return -1;
12329#endif
12330 }
12331 if (ss == 0) {
12332 return 0;
12333 }
12334 if (ss < 0) {
12335 if (maygvl_copy_stream_continue_p(has_gvl, stp))
12336 goto retry_read;
12337 switch (errno) {
12338 case EAGAIN:
12339#if EWOULDBLOCK != EAGAIN
12340 case EWOULDBLOCK:
12341#endif
12342 {
12343 int ret = maygvl_copy_stream_wait_read(has_gvl, stp);
12344 if (ret < 0) return ret;
12345 }
12346 goto retry_read;
12347#ifdef ENOSYS
12348 case ENOSYS:
12349 stp->notimp = "pread";
12350 return ss;
12351#endif
12352 }
12353 stp->syserr = offset < (off_t)0 ? "read" : "pread";
12354 stp->error_no = errno;
12355 }
12356 return ss;
12357}
12358
12359static int
12360nogvl_copy_stream_write(struct copy_stream_struct *stp, char *buf, size_t len)
12361{
12362 ssize_t ss;
12363 int off = 0;
12364 while (len) {
12365 ss = write(stp->dst_fptr->fd, buf+off, len);
12366 if (ss < 0) {
12367 if (maygvl_copy_stream_continue_p(0, stp))
12368 continue;
12369 if (io_again_p(errno)) {
12370 int ret = nogvl_copy_stream_wait_write(stp);
12371 if (ret < 0) return ret;
12372 continue;
12373 }
12374 stp->syserr = "write";
12375 stp->error_no = errno;
12376 return (int)ss;
12377 }
12378 off += (int)ss;
12379 len -= (int)ss;
12380 stp->total += ss;
12381 }
12382 return 0;
12383}
12384
12385static void
12386nogvl_copy_stream_read_write(struct copy_stream_struct *stp)
12387{
12388 char buf[1024*16];
12389 size_t len;
12390 ssize_t ss;
12391 int ret;
12392 off_t copy_length;
12393 int use_eof;
12394 off_t src_offset;
12395 int use_pread;
12396
12397 copy_length = stp->copy_length;
12398 use_eof = copy_length < (off_t)0;
12399 src_offset = stp->src_offset;
12400 use_pread = src_offset >= (off_t)0;
12401
12402 if (use_pread && stp->close_src) {
12403 off_t r;
12404 errno = 0;
12405 r = lseek(stp->src_fptr->fd, src_offset, SEEK_SET);
12406 if (r < (off_t)0 && errno) {
12407 stp->syserr = "lseek";
12408 stp->error_no = errno;
12409 return;
12410 }
12411 src_offset = (off_t)-1;
12412 use_pread = 0;
12413 }
12414
12415 while (use_eof || 0 < copy_length) {
12416 if (!use_eof && copy_length < (off_t)sizeof(buf)) {
12417 len = (size_t)copy_length;
12418 }
12419 else {
12420 len = sizeof(buf);
12421 }
12422 if (use_pread) {
12423 ss = maygvl_copy_stream_read(0, stp, buf, len, src_offset);
12424 if (0 < ss)
12425 src_offset += ss;
12426 }
12427 else {
12428 ss = maygvl_copy_stream_read(0, stp, buf, len, (off_t)-1);
12429 }
12430 if (ss <= 0) /* EOF or error */
12431 return;
12432
12433 ret = nogvl_copy_stream_write(stp, buf, ss);
12434 if (ret < 0)
12435 return;
12436
12437 if (!use_eof)
12438 copy_length -= ss;
12439 }
12440}
12441
12442static void *
12443nogvl_copy_stream_func(void *arg)
12444{
12445 struct copy_stream_struct *stp = (struct copy_stream_struct *)arg;
12446#if defined(USE_SENDFILE) || defined(USE_COPY_FILE_RANGE) || defined(HAVE_FCOPYFILE)
12447 int ret;
12448#endif
12449
12450#ifdef USE_COPY_FILE_RANGE
12451 ret = nogvl_copy_file_range(stp);
12452 if (ret != 0)
12453 goto finish; /* error or success */
12454#endif
12455
12456#ifdef HAVE_FCOPYFILE
12457 ret = nogvl_fcopyfile(stp);
12458 if (ret != 0)
12459 goto finish; /* error or success */
12460#endif
12461
12462#ifdef USE_SENDFILE
12463 ret = nogvl_copy_stream_sendfile(stp);
12464 if (ret != 0)
12465 goto finish; /* error or success */
12466#endif
12467
12468 nogvl_copy_stream_read_write(stp);
12469
12470#if defined(USE_SENDFILE) || defined(USE_COPY_FILE_RANGE) || defined(HAVE_FCOPYFILE)
12471 finish:
12472#endif
12473 return 0;
12474}
12475
12476static VALUE
12477copy_stream_fallback_body(VALUE arg)
12478{
12479 struct copy_stream_struct *stp = (struct copy_stream_struct *)arg;
12480 const int buflen = 16*1024;
12481 VALUE n;
12482 VALUE buf = rb_str_buf_new(buflen);
12483 off_t rest = stp->copy_length;
12484 off_t off = stp->src_offset;
12485 ID read_method = id_readpartial;
12486
12487 if (!stp->src_fptr) {
12488 if (!rb_respond_to(stp->src, read_method)) {
12489 read_method = id_read;
12490 }
12491 }
12492
12493 while (1) {
12494 long numwrote;
12495 long l;
12496 if (stp->copy_length < (off_t)0) {
12497 l = buflen;
12498 }
12499 else {
12500 if (rest == 0) {
12501 rb_str_resize(buf, 0);
12502 break;
12503 }
12504 l = buflen < rest ? buflen : (long)rest;
12505 }
12506 if (!stp->src_fptr) {
12507 VALUE rc = rb_funcall(stp->src, read_method, 2, INT2FIX(l), buf);
12508
12509 if (read_method == id_read && NIL_P(rc))
12510 break;
12511 }
12512 else {
12513 ssize_t ss;
12514 rb_str_resize(buf, buflen);
12515 ss = maygvl_copy_stream_read(1, stp, RSTRING_PTR(buf), l, off);
12516 rb_str_resize(buf, ss > 0 ? ss : 0);
12517 if (ss < 0)
12518 return Qnil;
12519 if (ss == 0)
12520 rb_eof_error();
12521 if (off >= (off_t)0)
12522 off += ss;
12523 }
12524 n = rb_io_write(stp->dst, buf);
12525 numwrote = NUM2LONG(n);
12526 stp->total += numwrote;
12527 rest -= numwrote;
12528 if (read_method == id_read && RSTRING_LEN(buf) == 0) {
12529 break;
12530 }
12531 }
12532
12533 return Qnil;
12534}
12535
12536static VALUE
12537copy_stream_fallback(struct copy_stream_struct *stp)
12538{
12539 if (!stp->src_fptr && stp->src_offset >= (off_t)0) {
12540 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "cannot specify src_offset for non-IO");
12541 }
12542 rb_rescue2(copy_stream_fallback_body, (VALUE)stp,
12543 (VALUE (*) (VALUE, VALUE))0, (VALUE)0,
12544 rb_eEOFError, (VALUE)0);
12545 return Qnil;
12546}
12547
12548static VALUE
12549copy_stream_body(VALUE arg)
12550{
12551 struct copy_stream_struct *stp = (struct copy_stream_struct *)arg;
12552 VALUE src_io = stp->src, dst_io = stp->dst;
12553 const int common_oflags = 0
12554#ifdef O_NOCTTY
12555 | O_NOCTTY
12556#endif
12557 ;
12558
12559 stp->th = rb_thread_current();
12560
12561 stp->total = 0;
12562
12563 if (src_io == argf ||
12564 !(RB_TYPE_P(src_io, T_FILE) ||
12565 RB_TYPE_P(src_io, T_STRING) ||
12566 rb_respond_to(src_io, rb_intern("to_path")))) {
12567 stp->src_fptr = NULL;
12568 }
12569 else {
12570 int stat_ret;
12571 VALUE tmp_io = rb_io_check_io(src_io);
12572 if (!NIL_P(tmp_io)) {
12573 src_io = tmp_io;
12574 }
12575 else if (!RB_TYPE_P(src_io, T_FILE)) {
12576 VALUE args[2];
12577 FilePathValue(src_io);
12578 args[0] = src_io;
12579 args[1] = INT2NUM(O_RDONLY|common_oflags);
12580 src_io = rb_class_new_instance(2, args, rb_cFile);
12581 stp->src = src_io;
12582 stp->close_src = 1;
12583 }
12584 RB_IO_POINTER(src_io, stp->src_fptr);
12585 rb_io_check_byte_readable(stp->src_fptr);
12586
12587 stat_ret = fstat(stp->src_fptr->fd, &stp->src_stat);
12588 if (stat_ret < 0) {
12589 stp->syserr = "fstat";
12590 stp->error_no = errno;
12591 return Qnil;
12592 }
12593 }
12594
12595 if (dst_io == argf ||
12596 !(RB_TYPE_P(dst_io, T_FILE) ||
12597 RB_TYPE_P(dst_io, T_STRING) ||
12598 rb_respond_to(dst_io, rb_intern("to_path")))) {
12599 stp->dst_fptr = NULL;
12600 }
12601 else {
12602 int stat_ret;
12603 VALUE tmp_io = rb_io_check_io(dst_io);
12604 if (!NIL_P(tmp_io)) {
12605 dst_io = GetWriteIO(tmp_io);
12606 }
12607 else if (!RB_TYPE_P(dst_io, T_FILE)) {
12608 VALUE args[3];
12609 FilePathValue(dst_io);
12610 args[0] = dst_io;
12611 args[1] = INT2NUM(O_WRONLY|O_CREAT|O_TRUNC|common_oflags);
12612 args[2] = INT2FIX(0666);
12613 dst_io = rb_class_new_instance(3, args, rb_cFile);
12614 stp->dst = dst_io;
12615 stp->close_dst = 1;
12616 }
12617 else {
12618 dst_io = GetWriteIO(dst_io);
12619 stp->dst = dst_io;
12620 }
12621 RB_IO_POINTER(dst_io, stp->dst_fptr);
12622 rb_io_check_writable(stp->dst_fptr);
12623
12624 stat_ret = fstat(stp->dst_fptr->fd, &stp->dst_stat);
12625 if (stat_ret < 0) {
12626 stp->syserr = "fstat";
12627 stp->error_no = errno;
12628 return Qnil;
12629 }
12630 }
12631
12632#ifdef O_BINARY
12633 if (stp->src_fptr)
12634 SET_BINARY_MODE_WITH_SEEK_CUR(stp->src_fptr);
12635#endif
12636 if (stp->dst_fptr)
12637 io_ascii8bit_binmode(stp->dst_fptr);
12638
12639 if (stp->src_offset < (off_t)0 && stp->src_fptr && stp->src_fptr->rbuf.len) {
12640 size_t len = stp->src_fptr->rbuf.len;
12641 VALUE str;
12642 if (stp->copy_length >= (off_t)0 && stp->copy_length < (off_t)len) {
12643 len = (size_t)stp->copy_length;
12644 }
12645 str = rb_str_buf_new(len);
12646 rb_str_resize(str,len);
12647 read_buffered_data(RSTRING_PTR(str), len, stp->src_fptr);
12648 if (stp->dst_fptr) { /* IO or filename */
12649 if (io_binwrite(str, RSTRING_PTR(str), RSTRING_LEN(str), stp->dst_fptr, 0) < 0)
12650 rb_sys_fail_on_write(stp->dst_fptr);
12651 }
12652 else /* others such as StringIO */
12653 rb_io_write(dst_io, str);
12654 rb_str_resize(str, 0);
12655 stp->total += len;
12656 if (stp->copy_length >= (off_t)0)
12657 stp->copy_length -= len;
12658 }
12659
12660 if (stp->dst_fptr && io_fflush(stp->dst_fptr) < 0) {
12661 rb_raise(rb_eIOError, "flush failed");
12662 }
12663
12664 if (stp->copy_length == 0)
12665 return Qnil;
12666
12667 if (stp->src_fptr == NULL || stp->dst_fptr == NULL) {
12668 return copy_stream_fallback(stp);
12669 }
12670
12671 rb_thread_call_without_gvl(nogvl_copy_stream_func, (void*)stp, RUBY_UBF_IO, 0);
12672 return Qnil;
12673}
12674
12675static VALUE
12676copy_stream_finalize(VALUE arg)
12677{
12678 struct copy_stream_struct *stp = (struct copy_stream_struct *)arg;
12679
12680#ifdef HAVE_FCOPYFILE
12681 if (stp->copyfile_state) {
12682 copyfile_state_free(stp->copyfile_state);
12683 }
12684#endif
12685
12686 if (stp->close_src) {
12687 rb_io_close_m(stp->src);
12688 }
12689 if (stp->close_dst) {
12690 rb_io_close_m(stp->dst);
12691 }
12692 if (stp->syserr) {
12693 rb_syserr_fail(stp->error_no, stp->syserr);
12694 }
12695 if (stp->notimp) {
12696 rb_raise(rb_eNotImpError, "%s() not implemented", stp->notimp);
12697 }
12698 return Qnil;
12699}
12700
12701/*
12702 * call-seq:
12703 * IO.copy_stream(src, dst, src_length = nil, src_offset = 0) -> integer
12704 *
12705 * Copies from the given +src+ to the given +dst+,
12706 * returning the number of bytes copied.
12707 *
12708 * - The given +src+ must be one of the following:
12709 *
12710 * - The path to a readable file, from which source data is to be read.
12711 * - An \IO-like object, opened for reading and capable of responding
12712 * to method +:readpartial+ or method +:read+.
12713 *
12714 * - The given +dst+ must be one of the following:
12715 *
12716 * - The path to a writable file, to which data is to be written.
12717 * - An \IO-like object, opened for writing and capable of responding
12718 * to method +:write+.
12719 *
12720 * The examples here use file <tt>t.txt</tt> as source:
12721 *
12722 * File.read('t.txt')
12723 * # => "First line\nSecond line\n\nThird line\nFourth line\n"
12724 * File.read('t.txt').size # => 47
12725 *
12726 * If only arguments +src+ and +dst+ are given,
12727 * the entire source stream is copied:
12728 *
12729 * # Paths.
12730 * IO.copy_stream('t.txt', 't.tmp') # => 47
12731 *
12732 * # IOs (recall that a File is also an IO).
12733 * src_io = File.open('t.txt', 'r') # => #<File:t.txt>
12734 * dst_io = File.open('t.tmp', 'w') # => #<File:t.tmp>
12735 * IO.copy_stream(src_io, dst_io) # => 47
12736 * src_io.close
12737 * dst_io.close
12738 *
12739 * With argument +src_length+ a non-negative integer,
12740 * no more than that many bytes are copied:
12741 *
12742 * IO.copy_stream('t.txt', 't.tmp', 10) # => 10
12743 * File.read('t.tmp') # => "First line"
12744 *
12745 * With argument +src_offset+ also given,
12746 * the source stream is read beginning at that offset:
12747 *
12748 * IO.copy_stream('t.txt', 't.tmp', 11, 11) # => 11
12749 * IO.read('t.tmp') # => "Second line"
12750 *
12751 */
12752static VALUE
12753rb_io_s_copy_stream(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE io)
12754{
12755 VALUE src, dst, length, src_offset;
12756 struct copy_stream_struct st;
12757
12758 MEMZERO(&st, struct copy_stream_struct, 1);
12759
12760 rb_scan_args(argc, argv, "22", &src, &dst, &length, &src_offset);
12761
12762 st.src = src;
12763 st.dst = dst;
12764
12765 st.src_fptr = NULL;
12766 st.dst_fptr = NULL;
12767
12768 if (NIL_P(length))
12769 st.copy_length = (off_t)-1;
12770 else
12771 st.copy_length = NUM2OFFT(length);
12772
12773 if (NIL_P(src_offset))
12774 st.src_offset = (off_t)-1;
12775 else
12776 st.src_offset = NUM2OFFT(src_offset);
12777
12778 rb_ensure(copy_stream_body, (VALUE)&st, copy_stream_finalize, (VALUE)&st);
12779
12780 return OFFT2NUM(st.total);
12781}
12782
12783/*
12784 * call-seq:
12785 * external_encoding -> encoding or nil
12786 *
12787 * Returns the Encoding object that represents the encoding of the stream,
12788 * or +nil+ if the stream is in write mode and no encoding is specified.
12789 *
12790 * See {Encodings}[rdoc-ref:IO@Encodings].
12791 *
12792 */
12793
12794static VALUE
12795rb_io_external_encoding(VALUE io)
12796{
12797 rb_io_t *fptr = RFILE(rb_io_taint_check(io))->fptr;
12798
12799 if (fptr->encs.enc2) {
12800 return rb_enc_from_encoding(fptr->encs.enc2);
12801 }
12802 if (fptr->mode & FMODE_WRITABLE) {
12803 if (fptr->encs.enc)
12804 return rb_enc_from_encoding(fptr->encs.enc);
12805 return Qnil;
12806 }
12807 return rb_enc_from_encoding(io_read_encoding(fptr));
12808}
12809
12810/*
12811 * call-seq:
12812 * internal_encoding -> encoding or nil
12813 *
12814 * Returns the Encoding object that represents the encoding of the internal string,
12815 * if conversion is specified,
12816 * or +nil+ otherwise.
12817 *
12818 * See {Encodings}[rdoc-ref:IO@Encodings].
12819 *
12820 */
12821
12822static VALUE
12823rb_io_internal_encoding(VALUE io)
12824{
12825 rb_io_t *fptr = RFILE(rb_io_taint_check(io))->fptr;
12826
12827 if (!fptr->encs.enc2) return Qnil;
12828 return rb_enc_from_encoding(io_read_encoding(fptr));
12829}
12830
12831/*
12832 * call-seq:
12833 * set_encoding(ext_enc) -> self
12834 * set_encoding(ext_enc, int_enc, **enc_opts) -> self
12835 * set_encoding('ext_enc:int_enc', **enc_opts) -> self
12836 *
12837 * See {Encodings}[rdoc-ref:IO@Encodings].
12838 *
12839 * Argument +ext_enc+, if given, must be an Encoding object;
12840 * it is assigned as the encoding for the stream.
12841 *
12842 * Argument +int_enc+, if given, must be an Encoding object;
12843 * it is assigned as the encoding for the internal string.
12844 *
12845 * Argument <tt>'ext_enc:int_enc'</tt>, if given, is a string
12846 * containing two colon-separated encoding names;
12847 * corresponding Encoding objects are assigned as the external
12848 * and internal encodings for the stream.
12849 *
12850 * Optional keyword arguments +enc_opts+ specify
12851 * {Encoding options}[rdoc-ref:encodings.rdoc@Encoding+Options].
12852 *
12853 */
12854
12855static VALUE
12856rb_io_set_encoding(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE io)
12857{
12858 rb_io_t *fptr;
12859 VALUE v1, v2, opt;
12860
12861 if (!RB_TYPE_P(io, T_FILE)) {
12862 return forward(io, id_set_encoding, argc, argv);
12863 }
12864
12865 argc = rb_scan_args(argc, argv, "11:", &v1, &v2, &opt);
12866 GetOpenFile(io, fptr);
12867 io_encoding_set(fptr, v1, v2, opt);
12868 return io;
12869}
12870
12871void
12872rb_stdio_set_default_encoding(void)
12873{
12874 VALUE val = Qnil;
12875
12876#ifdef _WIN32
12877 if (isatty(fileno(stdin))) {
12878 rb_encoding *external = rb_locale_encoding();
12879 rb_encoding *internal = rb_default_internal_encoding();
12880 if (!internal) internal = rb_default_external_encoding();
12881 io_encoding_set(RFILE(rb_stdin)->fptr,
12882 rb_enc_from_encoding(external),
12883 rb_enc_from_encoding(internal),
12884 Qnil);
12885 }
12886 else
12887#endif
12888 rb_io_set_encoding(1, &val, rb_stdin);
12889 rb_io_set_encoding(1, &val, rb_stdout);
12890 rb_io_set_encoding(1, &val, rb_stderr);
12891}
12892
12893static inline int
12894global_argf_p(VALUE arg)
12895{
12896 return arg == argf;
12897}
12898
12899/*
12900 * call-seq:
12901 * ARGF.external_encoding -> encoding
12902 *
12903 * Returns the external encoding for files read from +ARGF+ as an +Encoding+
12904 * object. The external encoding is the encoding of the text as stored in a
12905 * file. Contrast with +ARGF.internal_encoding+, which is the encoding used
12906 * to represent this text within Ruby.
12907 *
12908 * To set the external encoding use +ARGF.set_encoding+.
12909 *
12910 * For example:
12911 *
12912 * ARGF.external_encoding #=> #<Encoding:UTF-8>
12913 *
12914 */
12915static VALUE
12916argf_external_encoding(VALUE argf)
12917{
12918 if (!RTEST(ARGF.current_file)) {
12919 return rb_enc_from_encoding(rb_default_external_encoding());
12920 }
12921 return rb_io_external_encoding(rb_io_check_io(ARGF.current_file));
12922}
12923
12924/*
12925 * call-seq:
12926 * ARGF.internal_encoding -> encoding
12927 *
12928 * Returns the internal encoding for strings read from +ARGF+ as an
12929 * +Encoding+ object.
12930 *
12931 * If +ARGF.set_encoding+ has been called with two encoding names, the second
12932 * is returned. Otherwise, if +Encoding.default_external+ has been set, that
12933 * value is returned. Failing that, if a default external encoding was
12934 * specified on the command-line, that value is used. If the encoding is
12935 * unknown, +nil+ is returned.
12936 */
12937static VALUE
12938argf_internal_encoding(VALUE argf)
12939{
12940 if (!RTEST(ARGF.current_file)) {
12941 return rb_enc_from_encoding(rb_default_external_encoding());
12942 }
12943 return rb_io_internal_encoding(rb_io_check_io(ARGF.current_file));
12944}
12945
12946/*
12947 * call-seq:
12948 * ARGF.set_encoding(ext_enc) -> ARGF
12949 * ARGF.set_encoding("ext_enc:int_enc") -> ARGF
12950 * ARGF.set_encoding(ext_enc, int_enc) -> ARGF
12951 * ARGF.set_encoding("ext_enc:int_enc", opt) -> ARGF
12952 * ARGF.set_encoding(ext_enc, int_enc, opt) -> ARGF
12953 *
12954 * If single argument is specified, strings read from ARGF are tagged with
12955 * the encoding specified.
12956 *
12957 * If two encoding names separated by a colon are given, e.g. "ascii:utf-8",
12958 * the read string is converted from the first encoding (external encoding)
12959 * to the second encoding (internal encoding), then tagged with the second
12960 * encoding.
12961 *
12962 * If two arguments are specified, they must be encoding objects or encoding
12963 * names. Again, the first specifies the external encoding; the second
12964 * specifies the internal encoding.
12965 *
12966 * If the external encoding and the internal encoding are specified, the
12967 * optional +Hash+ argument can be used to adjust the conversion process. The
12968 * structure of this hash is explained in the String#encode documentation.
12969 *
12970 * For example:
12971 *
12972 * ARGF.set_encoding('ascii') # Tag the input as US-ASCII text
12973 * ARGF.set_encoding(Encoding::UTF_8) # Tag the input as UTF-8 text
12974 * ARGF.set_encoding('utf-8','ascii') # Transcode the input from US-ASCII
12975 * # to UTF-8.
12976 */
12977static VALUE
12978argf_set_encoding(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
12979{
12980 rb_io_t *fptr;
12981
12982 if (!next_argv()) {
12983 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream to set encoding");
12984 }
12985 rb_io_set_encoding(argc, argv, ARGF.current_file);
12986 GetOpenFile(ARGF.current_file, fptr);
12987 ARGF.encs = fptr->encs;
12988 return argf;
12989}
12990
12991/*
12992 * call-seq:
12993 * ARGF.tell -> Integer
12994 * ARGF.pos -> Integer
12995 *
12996 * Returns the current offset (in bytes) of the current file in +ARGF+.
12997 *
12998 * ARGF.pos #=> 0
12999 * ARGF.gets #=> "This is line one\n"
13000 * ARGF.pos #=> 17
13001 *
13002 */
13003static VALUE
13004argf_tell(VALUE argf)
13005{
13006 if (!next_argv()) {
13007 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream to tell");
13008 }
13009 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13010 return rb_io_tell(ARGF.current_file);
13011}
13012
13013/*
13014 * call-seq:
13015 * ARGF.seek(amount, whence=IO::SEEK_SET) -> 0
13016 *
13017 * Seeks to offset _amount_ (an +Integer+) in the +ARGF+ stream according to
13018 * the value of _whence_. See IO#seek for further details.
13019 */
13020static VALUE
13021argf_seek_m(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13022{
13023 if (!next_argv()) {
13024 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream to seek");
13025 }
13026 ARGF_FORWARD(argc, argv);
13027 return rb_io_seek_m(argc, argv, ARGF.current_file);
13028}
13029
13030/*
13031 * call-seq:
13032 * ARGF.pos = position -> Integer
13033 *
13034 * Seeks to the position given by _position_ (in bytes) in +ARGF+.
13035 *
13036 * For example:
13037 *
13038 * ARGF.pos = 17
13039 * ARGF.gets #=> "This is line two\n"
13040 */
13041static VALUE
13042argf_set_pos(VALUE argf, VALUE offset)
13043{
13044 if (!next_argv()) {
13045 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream to set position");
13046 }
13047 ARGF_FORWARD(1, &offset);
13048 return rb_io_set_pos(ARGF.current_file, offset);
13049}
13050
13051/*
13052 * call-seq:
13053 * ARGF.rewind -> 0
13054 *
13055 * Positions the current file to the beginning of input, resetting
13056 * +ARGF.lineno+ to zero.
13057 *
13058 * ARGF.readline #=> "This is line one\n"
13059 * ARGF.rewind #=> 0
13060 * ARGF.lineno #=> 0
13061 * ARGF.readline #=> "This is line one\n"
13062 */
13063static VALUE
13064argf_rewind(VALUE argf)
13065{
13066 VALUE ret;
13067 int old_lineno;
13068
13069 if (!next_argv()) {
13070 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream to rewind");
13071 }
13072 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13073 old_lineno = RFILE(ARGF.current_file)->fptr->lineno;
13074 ret = rb_io_rewind(ARGF.current_file);
13075 if (!global_argf_p(argf)) {
13076 ARGF.last_lineno = ARGF.lineno -= old_lineno;
13077 }
13078 return ret;
13079}
13080
13081/*
13082 * call-seq:
13083 * ARGF.fileno -> integer
13084 * ARGF.to_i -> integer
13085 *
13086 * Returns an integer representing the numeric file descriptor for
13087 * the current file. Raises an +ArgumentError+ if there isn't a current file.
13088 *
13089 * ARGF.fileno #=> 3
13090 */
13091static VALUE
13092argf_fileno(VALUE argf)
13093{
13094 if (!next_argv()) {
13095 rb_raise(rb_eArgError, "no stream");
13096 }
13097 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13098 return rb_io_fileno(ARGF.current_file);
13099}
13100
13101/*
13102 * call-seq:
13103 * ARGF.to_io -> IO
13104 *
13105 * Returns an +IO+ object representing the current file. This will be a
13106 * +File+ object unless the current file is a stream such as STDIN.
13107 *
13108 * For example:
13109 *
13110 * ARGF.to_io #=> #<File:glark.txt>
13111 * ARGF.to_io #=> #<IO:<STDIN>>
13112 */
13113static VALUE
13114argf_to_io(VALUE argf)
13115{
13116 next_argv();
13117 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13118 return ARGF.current_file;
13119}
13120
13121/*
13122 * call-seq:
13123 * ARGF.eof? -> true or false
13124 * ARGF.eof -> true or false
13125 *
13126 * Returns true if the current file in +ARGF+ is at end of file, i.e. it has
13127 * no data to read. The stream must be opened for reading or an +IOError+
13128 * will be raised.
13129 *
13130 * $ echo "eof" | ruby argf.rb
13131 *
13132 * ARGF.eof? #=> false
13133 * 3.times { ARGF.readchar }
13134 * ARGF.eof? #=> false
13135 * ARGF.readchar #=> "\n"
13136 * ARGF.eof? #=> true
13137 */
13138
13139static VALUE
13140argf_eof(VALUE argf)
13141{
13142 next_argv();
13143 if (RTEST(ARGF.current_file)) {
13144 if (ARGF.init_p == 0) return Qtrue;
13145 next_argv();
13146 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13147 if (rb_io_eof(ARGF.current_file)) {
13148 return Qtrue;
13149 }
13150 }
13151 return Qfalse;
13152}
13153
13154/*
13155 * call-seq:
13156 * ARGF.read([length [, outbuf]]) -> string, outbuf, or nil
13157 *
13158 * Reads _length_ bytes from ARGF. The files named on the command line
13159 * are concatenated and treated as a single file by this method, so when
13160 * called without arguments the contents of this pseudo file are returned in
13161 * their entirety.
13162 *
13163 * _length_ must be a non-negative integer or +nil+.
13164 *
13165 * If _length_ is a positive integer, +read+ tries to read
13166 * _length_ bytes without any conversion (binary mode).
13167 * It returns +nil+ if an EOF is encountered before anything can be read.
13168 * Fewer than _length_ bytes are returned if an EOF is encountered during
13169 * the read.
13170 * In the case of an integer _length_, the resulting string is always
13171 * in ASCII-8BIT encoding.
13172 *
13173 * If _length_ is omitted or is +nil+, it reads until EOF
13174 * and the encoding conversion is applied, if applicable.
13175 * A string is returned even if EOF is encountered before any data is read.
13176 *
13177 * If _length_ is zero, it returns an empty string (<code>""</code>).
13178 *
13179 * If the optional _outbuf_ argument is present,
13180 * it must reference a String, which will receive the data.
13181 * The _outbuf_ will contain only the received data after the method call
13182 * even if it is not empty at the beginning.
13183 *
13184 * For example:
13185 *
13186 * $ echo "small" > small.txt
13187 * $ echo "large" > large.txt
13188 * $ ./glark.rb small.txt large.txt
13189 *
13190 * ARGF.read #=> "small\nlarge"
13191 * ARGF.read(200) #=> "small\nlarge"
13192 * ARGF.read(2) #=> "sm"
13193 * ARGF.read(0) #=> ""
13194 *
13195 * Note that this method behaves like the fread() function in C.
13196 * This means it retries to invoke read(2) system calls to read data
13197 * with the specified length.
13198 * If you need the behavior like a single read(2) system call,
13199 * consider ARGF#readpartial or ARGF#read_nonblock.
13200 */
13201
13202static VALUE
13203argf_read(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13204{
13205 VALUE tmp, str, length;
13206 long len = 0;
13207
13208 rb_scan_args(argc, argv, "02", &length, &str);
13209 if (!NIL_P(length)) {
13210 len = NUM2LONG(argv[0]);
13211 }
13212 if (!NIL_P(str)) {
13213 StringValue(str);
13214 rb_str_resize(str,0);
13215 argv[1] = Qnil;
13216 }
13217
13218 retry:
13219 if (!next_argv()) {
13220 return str;
13221 }
13222 if (ARGF_GENERIC_INPUT_P()) {
13223 tmp = argf_forward(argc, argv, argf);
13224 }
13225 else {
13226 tmp = io_read(argc, argv, ARGF.current_file);
13227 }
13228 if (NIL_P(str)) str = tmp;
13229 else if (!NIL_P(tmp)) rb_str_append(str, tmp);
13230 if (NIL_P(tmp) || NIL_P(length)) {
13231 if (ARGF.next_p != -1) {
13232 argf_close(argf);
13233 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13234 goto retry;
13235 }
13236 }
13237 else if (argc >= 1) {
13238 long slen = RSTRING_LEN(str);
13239 if (slen < len) {
13240 argv[0] = LONG2NUM(len - slen);
13241 goto retry;
13242 }
13243 }
13244 return str;
13245}
13246
13247struct argf_call_arg {
13248 int argc;
13249 VALUE *argv;
13250 VALUE argf;
13251};
13252
13253static VALUE
13254argf_forward_call(VALUE arg)
13255{
13256 struct argf_call_arg *p = (struct argf_call_arg *)arg;
13257 argf_forward(p->argc, p->argv, p->argf);
13258 return Qnil;
13259}
13260
13261static VALUE argf_getpartial(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf, VALUE opts,
13262 int nonblock);
13263
13264/*
13265 * call-seq:
13266 * ARGF.readpartial(maxlen) -> string
13267 * ARGF.readpartial(maxlen, outbuf) -> outbuf
13268 *
13269 * Reads at most _maxlen_ bytes from the ARGF stream.
13270 *
13271 * If the optional _outbuf_ argument is present,
13272 * it must reference a String, which will receive the data.
13273 * The _outbuf_ will contain only the received data after the method call
13274 * even if it is not empty at the beginning.
13275 *
13276 * It raises EOFError on end of ARGF stream.
13277 * Since ARGF stream is a concatenation of multiple files,
13278 * internally EOF is occur for each file.
13279 * ARGF.readpartial returns empty strings for EOFs except the last one and
13280 * raises EOFError for the last one.
13281 *
13282 */
13283
13284static VALUE
13285argf_readpartial(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13286{
13287 return argf_getpartial(argc, argv, argf, Qnil, 0);
13288}
13289
13290/*
13291 * call-seq:
13292 * ARGF.read_nonblock(maxlen[, options]) -> string
13293 * ARGF.read_nonblock(maxlen, outbuf[, options]) -> outbuf
13294 *
13295 * Reads at most _maxlen_ bytes from the ARGF stream in non-blocking mode.
13296 */
13297
13298static VALUE
13299argf_read_nonblock(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13300{
13301 VALUE opts;
13302
13303 rb_scan_args(argc, argv, "11:", NULL, NULL, &opts);
13304
13305 if (!NIL_P(opts))
13306 argc--;
13307
13308 return argf_getpartial(argc, argv, argf, opts, 1);
13309}
13310
13311static VALUE
13312argf_getpartial(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf, VALUE opts, int nonblock)
13313{
13314 VALUE tmp, str, length;
13315 int no_exception;
13316
13317 rb_scan_args(argc, argv, "11", &length, &str);
13318 if (!NIL_P(str)) {
13319 StringValue(str);
13320 argv[1] = str;
13321 }
13322 no_exception = no_exception_p(opts);
13323
13324 if (!next_argv()) {
13325 if (!NIL_P(str)) {
13326 rb_str_resize(str, 0);
13327 }
13328 rb_eof_error();
13329 }
13330 if (ARGF_GENERIC_INPUT_P()) {
13331 VALUE (*const rescue_does_nothing)(VALUE, VALUE) = 0;
13332 struct argf_call_arg arg;
13333 arg.argc = argc;
13334 arg.argv = argv;
13335 arg.argf = argf;
13336 tmp = rb_rescue2(argf_forward_call, (VALUE)&arg,
13337 rescue_does_nothing, Qnil, rb_eEOFError, (VALUE)0);
13338 }
13339 else {
13340 tmp = io_getpartial(argc, argv, ARGF.current_file, no_exception, nonblock);
13341 }
13342 if (NIL_P(tmp)) {
13343 if (ARGF.next_p == -1) {
13344 return io_nonblock_eof(no_exception);
13345 }
13346 argf_close(argf);
13347 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13348 if (RARRAY_LEN(ARGF.argv) == 0) {
13349 return io_nonblock_eof(no_exception);
13350 }
13351 if (NIL_P(str))
13352 str = rb_str_new(NULL, 0);
13353 return str;
13354 }
13355 return tmp;
13356}
13357
13358/*
13359 * call-seq:
13360 * ARGF.getc -> String or nil
13361 *
13362 * Reads the next character from +ARGF+ and returns it as a +String+. Returns
13363 * +nil+ at the end of the stream.
13364 *
13365 * +ARGF+ treats the files named on the command line as a single file created
13366 * by concatenating their contents. After returning the last character of the
13367 * first file, it returns the first character of the second file, and so on.
13368 *
13369 * For example:
13370 *
13371 * $ echo "foo" > file
13372 * $ ruby argf.rb file
13373 *
13374 * ARGF.getc #=> "f"
13375 * ARGF.getc #=> "o"
13376 * ARGF.getc #=> "o"
13377 * ARGF.getc #=> "\n"
13378 * ARGF.getc #=> nil
13379 * ARGF.getc #=> nil
13380 */
13381static VALUE
13382argf_getc(VALUE argf)
13383{
13384 VALUE ch;
13385
13386 retry:
13387 if (!next_argv()) return Qnil;
13388 if (ARGF_GENERIC_INPUT_P()) {
13389 ch = forward_current(rb_intern("getc"), 0, 0);
13390 }
13391 else {
13392 ch = rb_io_getc(ARGF.current_file);
13393 }
13394 if (NIL_P(ch) && ARGF.next_p != -1) {
13395 argf_close(argf);
13396 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13397 goto retry;
13398 }
13399
13400 return ch;
13401}
13402
13403/*
13404 * call-seq:
13405 * ARGF.getbyte -> Integer or nil
13406 *
13407 * Gets the next 8-bit byte (0..255) from +ARGF+. Returns +nil+ if called at
13408 * the end of the stream.
13409 *
13410 * For example:
13411 *
13412 * $ echo "foo" > file
13413 * $ ruby argf.rb file
13414 *
13415 * ARGF.getbyte #=> 102
13416 * ARGF.getbyte #=> 111
13417 * ARGF.getbyte #=> 111
13418 * ARGF.getbyte #=> 10
13419 * ARGF.getbyte #=> nil
13420 */
13421static VALUE
13422argf_getbyte(VALUE argf)
13423{
13424 VALUE ch;
13425
13426 retry:
13427 if (!next_argv()) return Qnil;
13428 if (!RB_TYPE_P(ARGF.current_file, T_FILE)) {
13429 ch = forward_current(rb_intern("getbyte"), 0, 0);
13430 }
13431 else {
13432 ch = rb_io_getbyte(ARGF.current_file);
13433 }
13434 if (NIL_P(ch) && ARGF.next_p != -1) {
13435 argf_close(argf);
13436 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13437 goto retry;
13438 }
13439
13440 return ch;
13441}
13442
13443/*
13444 * call-seq:
13445 * ARGF.readchar -> String or nil
13446 *
13447 * Reads the next character from +ARGF+ and returns it as a +String+. Raises
13448 * an +EOFError+ after the last character of the last file has been read.
13449 *
13450 * For example:
13451 *
13452 * $ echo "foo" > file
13453 * $ ruby argf.rb file
13454 *
13455 * ARGF.readchar #=> "f"
13456 * ARGF.readchar #=> "o"
13457 * ARGF.readchar #=> "o"
13458 * ARGF.readchar #=> "\n"
13459 * ARGF.readchar #=> end of file reached (EOFError)
13460 */
13461static VALUE
13462argf_readchar(VALUE argf)
13463{
13464 VALUE ch;
13465
13466 retry:
13467 if (!next_argv()) rb_eof_error();
13468 if (!RB_TYPE_P(ARGF.current_file, T_FILE)) {
13469 ch = forward_current(rb_intern("getc"), 0, 0);
13470 }
13471 else {
13472 ch = rb_io_getc(ARGF.current_file);
13473 }
13474 if (NIL_P(ch) && ARGF.next_p != -1) {
13475 argf_close(argf);
13476 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13477 goto retry;
13478 }
13479
13480 return ch;
13481}
13482
13483/*
13484 * call-seq:
13485 * ARGF.readbyte -> Integer
13486 *
13487 * Reads the next 8-bit byte from ARGF and returns it as an +Integer+. Raises
13488 * an +EOFError+ after the last byte of the last file has been read.
13489 *
13490 * For example:
13491 *
13492 * $ echo "foo" > file
13493 * $ ruby argf.rb file
13494 *
13495 * ARGF.readbyte #=> 102
13496 * ARGF.readbyte #=> 111
13497 * ARGF.readbyte #=> 111
13498 * ARGF.readbyte #=> 10
13499 * ARGF.readbyte #=> end of file reached (EOFError)
13500 */
13501static VALUE
13502argf_readbyte(VALUE argf)
13503{
13504 VALUE c;
13505
13506 NEXT_ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13507 c = argf_getbyte(argf);
13508 if (NIL_P(c)) {
13509 rb_eof_error();
13510 }
13511 return c;
13512}
13513
13514#define FOREACH_ARGF() while (next_argv())
13515
13516static VALUE
13517argf_block_call_i(RB_BLOCK_CALL_FUNC_ARGLIST(i, argf))
13518{
13519 const VALUE current = ARGF.current_file;
13520 rb_yield_values2(argc, argv);
13521 if (ARGF.init_p == -1 || current != ARGF.current_file) {
13522 rb_iter_break_value(Qundef);
13523 }
13524 return Qnil;
13525}
13526
13527#define ARGF_block_call(mid, argc, argv, func, argf) \
13528 rb_block_call_kw(ARGF.current_file, mid, argc, argv, \
13529 func, argf, rb_keyword_given_p())
13530
13531static void
13532argf_block_call(ID mid, int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13533{
13534 VALUE ret = ARGF_block_call(mid, argc, argv, argf_block_call_i, argf);
13535 if (ret != Qundef) ARGF.next_p = 1;
13536}
13537
13538static VALUE
13539argf_block_call_line_i(RB_BLOCK_CALL_FUNC_ARGLIST(i, argf))
13540{
13541 if (!global_argf_p(argf)) {
13542 ARGF.last_lineno = ++ARGF.lineno;
13543 }
13544 return argf_block_call_i(i, argf, argc, argv, blockarg);
13545}
13546
13547static void
13548argf_block_call_line(ID mid, int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13549{
13550 VALUE ret = ARGF_block_call(mid, argc, argv, argf_block_call_line_i, argf);
13551 if (ret != Qundef) ARGF.next_p = 1;
13552}
13553
13554/*
13555 * call-seq:
13556 * ARGF.each(sep=$/) {|line| block } -> ARGF
13557 * ARGF.each(sep=$/, limit) {|line| block } -> ARGF
13558 * ARGF.each(...) -> an_enumerator
13559 *
13560 * ARGF.each_line(sep=$/) {|line| block } -> ARGF
13561 * ARGF.each_line(sep=$/, limit) {|line| block } -> ARGF
13562 * ARGF.each_line(...) -> an_enumerator
13563 *
13564 * Returns an enumerator which iterates over each line (separated by _sep_,
13565 * which defaults to your platform's newline character) of each file in
13566 * +ARGV+. If a block is supplied, each line in turn will be yielded to the
13567 * block, otherwise an enumerator is returned.
13568 * The optional _limit_ argument is an +Integer+ specifying the maximum
13569 * length of each line; longer lines will be split according to this limit.
13570 *
13571 * This method allows you to treat the files supplied on the command line as
13572 * a single file consisting of the concatenation of each named file. After
13573 * the last line of the first file has been returned, the first line of the
13574 * second file is returned. The +ARGF.filename+ and +ARGF.lineno+ methods can
13575 * be used to determine the filename of the current line and line number of
13576 * the whole input, respectively.
13577 *
13578 * For example, the following code prints out each line of each named file
13579 * prefixed with its line number, displaying the filename once per file:
13580 *
13581 * ARGF.each_line do |line|
13582 * puts ARGF.filename if ARGF.file.lineno == 1
13583 * puts "#{ARGF.file.lineno}: #{line}"
13584 * end
13585 *
13586 * While the following code prints only the first file's name at first, and
13587 * the contents with line number counted through all named files.
13588 *
13589 * ARGF.each_line do |line|
13590 * puts ARGF.filename if ARGF.lineno == 1
13591 * puts "#{ARGF.lineno}: #{line}"
13592 * end
13593 */
13594static VALUE
13595argf_each_line(int argc, VALUE *argv, VALUE argf)
13596{
13597 RETURN_ENUMERATOR(argf, argc, argv);
13598 FOREACH_ARGF() {
13599 argf_block_call_line(rb_intern("each_line"), argc, argv, argf);
13600 }
13601 return argf;
13602}
13603
13604/*
13605 * call-seq:
13606 * ARGF.each_byte {|byte| block } -> ARGF
13607 * ARGF.each_byte -> an_enumerator
13608 *
13609 * Iterates over each byte of each file in +ARGV+.
13610 * A byte is returned as an +Integer+ in the range 0..255.
13611 *
13612 * This method allows you to treat the files supplied on the command line as
13613 * a single file consisting of the concatenation of each named file. After
13614 * the last byte of the first file has been returned, the first byte of the
13615 * second file is returned. The +ARGF.filename+ method can be used to
13616 * determine the filename of the current byte.
13617 *
13618 * If no block is given, an enumerator is returned instead.
13619 *
13620 * For example:
13621 *
13622 * ARGF.bytes.to_a #=> [35, 32, ... 95, 10]
13623 *
13624 */
13625static VALUE
13626argf_each_byte(VALUE argf)
13627{
13628 RETURN_ENUMERATOR(argf, 0, 0);
13629 FOREACH_ARGF() {
13630 argf_block_call(rb_intern("each_byte"), 0, 0, argf);
13631 }
13632 return argf;
13633}
13634
13635/*
13636 * call-seq:
13637 * ARGF.each_char {|char| block } -> ARGF
13638 * ARGF.each_char -> an_enumerator
13639 *
13640 * Iterates over each character of each file in +ARGF+.
13641 *
13642 * This method allows you to treat the files supplied on the command line as
13643 * a single file consisting of the concatenation of each named file. After
13644 * the last character of the first file has been returned, the first
13645 * character of the second file is returned. The +ARGF.filename+ method can
13646 * be used to determine the name of the file in which the current character
13647 * appears.
13648 *
13649 * If no block is given, an enumerator is returned instead.
13650 */
13651static VALUE
13652argf_each_char(VALUE argf)
13653{
13654 RETURN_ENUMERATOR(argf, 0, 0);
13655 FOREACH_ARGF() {
13656 argf_block_call(rb_intern("each_char"), 0, 0, argf);
13657 }
13658 return argf;
13659}
13660
13661/*
13662 * call-seq:
13663 * ARGF.each_codepoint {|codepoint| block } -> ARGF
13664 * ARGF.each_codepoint -> an_enumerator
13665 *
13666 * Iterates over each codepoint of each file in +ARGF+.
13667 *
13668 * This method allows you to treat the files supplied on the command line as
13669 * a single file consisting of the concatenation of each named file. After
13670 * the last codepoint of the first file has been returned, the first
13671 * codepoint of the second file is returned. The +ARGF.filename+ method can
13672 * be used to determine the name of the file in which the current codepoint
13673 * appears.
13674 *
13675 * If no block is given, an enumerator is returned instead.
13676 */
13677static VALUE
13678argf_each_codepoint(VALUE argf)
13679{
13680 RETURN_ENUMERATOR(argf, 0, 0);
13681 FOREACH_ARGF() {
13682 argf_block_call(rb_intern("each_codepoint"), 0, 0, argf);
13683 }
13684 return argf;
13685}
13686
13687/*
13688 * call-seq:
13689 * ARGF.filename -> String
13690 * ARGF.path -> String
13691 *
13692 * Returns the current filename. "-" is returned when the current file is
13693 * STDIN.
13694 *
13695 * For example:
13696 *
13697 * $ echo "foo" > foo
13698 * $ echo "bar" > bar
13699 * $ echo "glark" > glark
13700 *
13701 * $ ruby argf.rb foo bar glark
13702 *
13703 * ARGF.filename #=> "foo"
13704 * ARGF.read(5) #=> "foo\nb"
13705 * ARGF.filename #=> "bar"
13706 * ARGF.skip
13707 * ARGF.filename #=> "glark"
13708 */
13709static VALUE
13710argf_filename(VALUE argf)
13711{
13712 next_argv();
13713 return ARGF.filename;
13714}
13715
13716static VALUE
13717argf_filename_getter(ID id, VALUE *var)
13718{
13719 return argf_filename(*var);
13720}
13721
13722/*
13723 * call-seq:
13724 * ARGF.file -> IO or File object
13725 *
13726 * Returns the current file as an +IO+ or +File+ object.
13727 * <code>$stdin</code> is returned when the current file is STDIN.
13728 *
13729 * For example:
13730 *
13731 * $ echo "foo" > foo
13732 * $ echo "bar" > bar
13733 *
13734 * $ ruby argf.rb foo bar
13735 *
13736 * ARGF.file #=> #<File:foo>
13737 * ARGF.read(5) #=> "foo\nb"
13738 * ARGF.file #=> #<File:bar>
13739 */
13740static VALUE
13741argf_file(VALUE argf)
13742{
13743 next_argv();
13744 return ARGF.current_file;
13745}
13746
13747/*
13748 * call-seq:
13749 * ARGF.binmode -> ARGF
13750 *
13751 * Puts +ARGF+ into binary mode. Once a stream is in binary mode, it cannot
13752 * be reset to non-binary mode. This option has the following effects:
13753 *
13754 * * Newline conversion is disabled.
13755 * * Encoding conversion is disabled.
13756 * * Content is treated as ASCII-8BIT.
13757 */
13758static VALUE
13759argf_binmode_m(VALUE argf)
13760{
13761 ARGF.binmode = 1;
13762 next_argv();
13763 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13764 rb_io_ascii8bit_binmode(ARGF.current_file);
13765 return argf;
13766}
13767
13768/*
13769 * call-seq:
13770 * ARGF.binmode? -> true or false
13771 *
13772 * Returns true if +ARGF+ is being read in binary mode; false otherwise.
13773 * To enable binary mode use +ARGF.binmode+.
13774 *
13775 * For example:
13776 *
13777 * ARGF.binmode? #=> false
13778 * ARGF.binmode
13779 * ARGF.binmode? #=> true
13780 */
13781static VALUE
13782argf_binmode_p(VALUE argf)
13783{
13784 return RBOOL(ARGF.binmode);
13785}
13786
13787/*
13788 * call-seq:
13789 * ARGF.skip -> ARGF
13790 *
13791 * Sets the current file to the next file in ARGV. If there aren't any more
13792 * files it has no effect.
13793 *
13794 * For example:
13795 *
13796 * $ ruby argf.rb foo bar
13797 * ARGF.filename #=> "foo"
13798 * ARGF.skip
13799 * ARGF.filename #=> "bar"
13800 */
13801static VALUE
13802argf_skip(VALUE argf)
13803{
13804 if (ARGF.init_p && ARGF.next_p == 0) {
13805 argf_close(argf);
13806 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13807 }
13808 return argf;
13809}
13810
13811/*
13812 * call-seq:
13813 * ARGF.close -> ARGF
13814 *
13815 * Closes the current file and skips to the next file in ARGV. If there are
13816 * no more files to open, just closes the current file. +STDIN+ will not be
13817 * closed.
13818 *
13819 * For example:
13820 *
13821 * $ ruby argf.rb foo bar
13822 *
13823 * ARGF.filename #=> "foo"
13824 * ARGF.close
13825 * ARGF.filename #=> "bar"
13826 * ARGF.close
13827 */
13828static VALUE
13829argf_close_m(VALUE argf)
13830{
13831 next_argv();
13832 argf_close(argf);
13833 if (ARGF.next_p != -1) {
13834 ARGF.next_p = 1;
13835 }
13836 ARGF.lineno = 0;
13837 return argf;
13838}
13839
13840/*
13841 * call-seq:
13842 * ARGF.closed? -> true or false
13843 *
13844 * Returns _true_ if the current file has been closed; _false_ otherwise. Use
13845 * +ARGF.close+ to actually close the current file.
13846 */
13847static VALUE
13848argf_closed(VALUE argf)
13849{
13850 next_argv();
13851 ARGF_FORWARD(0, 0);
13852 return rb_io_closed(ARGF.current_file);
13853}
13854
13855/*
13856 * call-seq:
13857 * ARGF.to_s -> String
13858 *
13859 * Returns "ARGF".
13860 */
13861static VALUE
13862argf_to_s(VALUE argf)
13863{
13864 return rb_str_new2("ARGF");
13865}
13866
13867/*
13868 * call-seq:
13869 * ARGF.inplace_mode -> String
13870 *
13871 * Returns the file extension appended to the names of modified files under
13872 * in-place edit mode. This value can be set using +ARGF.inplace_mode=+ or
13873 * passing the +-i+ switch to the Ruby binary.
13874 */
13875static VALUE
13876argf_inplace_mode_get(VALUE argf)
13877{
13878 if (!ARGF.inplace) return Qnil;
13879 if (NIL_P(ARGF.inplace)) return rb_str_new(0, 0);
13880 return rb_str_dup(ARGF.inplace);
13881}
13882
13883static VALUE
13884opt_i_get(ID id, VALUE *var)
13885{
13886 return argf_inplace_mode_get(*var);
13887}
13888
13889/*
13890 * call-seq:
13891 * ARGF.inplace_mode = ext -> ARGF
13892 *
13893 * Sets the filename extension for in-place editing mode to the given String.
13894 * Each file being edited has this value appended to its filename. The
13895 * modified file is saved under this new name.
13896 *
13897 * For example:
13898 *
13899 * $ ruby argf.rb file.txt
13900 *
13901 * ARGF.inplace_mode = '.bak'
13902 * ARGF.each_line do |line|
13903 * print line.sub("foo","bar")
13904 * end
13905 *
13906 * Each line of _file.txt_ has the first occurrence of "foo" replaced with
13907 * "bar", then the new line is written out to _file.txt.bak_.
13908 */
13909static VALUE
13910argf_inplace_mode_set(VALUE argf, VALUE val)
13911{
13912 if (!RTEST(val)) {
13913 ARGF.inplace = Qfalse;
13914 }
13915 else if (StringValueCStr(val), !RSTRING_LEN(val)) {
13916 ARGF.inplace = Qnil;
13917 }
13918 else {
13919 ARGF.inplace = rb_str_new_frozen(val);
13920 }
13921 return argf;
13922}
13923
13924static void
13925opt_i_set(VALUE val, ID id, VALUE *var)
13926{
13927 argf_inplace_mode_set(*var, val);
13928}
13929
13930void
13931ruby_set_inplace_mode(const char *suffix)
13932{
13933 ARGF.inplace = !suffix ? Qfalse : !*suffix ? Qnil : rb_str_new(suffix, strlen(suffix));
13934}
13935
13936/*
13937 * call-seq:
13938 * ARGF.argv -> ARGV
13939 *
13940 * Returns the +ARGV+ array, which contains the arguments passed to your
13941 * script, one per element.
13942 *
13943 * For example:
13944 *
13945 * $ ruby argf.rb -v glark.txt
13946 *
13947 * ARGF.argv #=> ["-v", "glark.txt"]
13948 *
13949 */
13950static VALUE
13951argf_argv(VALUE argf)
13952{
13953 return ARGF.argv;
13954}
13955
13956static VALUE
13957argf_argv_getter(ID id, VALUE *var)
13958{
13959 return argf_argv(*var);
13960}
13961
13962VALUE
13963rb_get_argv(void)
13964{
13965 return ARGF.argv;
13966}
13967
13968/*
13969 * call-seq:
13970 * ARGF.to_write_io -> io
13971 *
13972 * Returns IO instance tied to _ARGF_ for writing if inplace mode is
13973 * enabled.
13974 */
13975static VALUE
13976argf_write_io(VALUE argf)
13977{
13978 if (!RTEST(ARGF.current_file)) {
13979 rb_raise(rb_eIOError, "not opened for writing");
13980 }
13981 return GetWriteIO(ARGF.current_file);
13982}
13983
13984/*
13985 * call-seq:
13986 * ARGF.write(string) -> integer
13987 *
13988 * Writes _string_ if inplace mode.
13989 */
13990static VALUE
13991argf_write(VALUE argf, VALUE str)
13992{
13993 return rb_io_write(argf_write_io(argf), str);
13994}
13995
13996void
13997rb_readwrite_sys_fail(enum rb_io_wait_readwrite waiting, const char *mesg)
13998{
13999 rb_readwrite_syserr_fail(waiting, errno, mesg);
14000}
14001
14002void
14003rb_readwrite_syserr_fail(enum rb_io_wait_readwrite waiting, int n, const char *mesg)
14004{
14005 VALUE arg, c = Qnil;
14006 arg = mesg ? rb_str_new2(mesg) : Qnil;
14007 switch (waiting) {
14008 case RB_IO_WAIT_WRITABLE:
14009 switch (n) {
14010 case EAGAIN:
14011 c = rb_eEAGAINWaitWritable;
14012 break;
14013#if EAGAIN != EWOULDBLOCK
14014 case EWOULDBLOCK:
14015 c = rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable;
14016 break;
14017#endif
14018 case EINPROGRESS:
14019 c = rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitWritable;
14020 break;
14021 default:
14022 rb_mod_syserr_fail_str(rb_mWaitWritable, n, arg);
14023 }
14024 break;
14025 case RB_IO_WAIT_READABLE:
14026 switch (n) {
14027 case EAGAIN:
14028 c = rb_eEAGAINWaitReadable;
14029 break;
14030#if EAGAIN != EWOULDBLOCK
14031 case EWOULDBLOCK:
14032 c = rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable;
14033 break;
14034#endif
14035 case EINPROGRESS:
14036 c = rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitReadable;
14037 break;
14038 default:
14039 rb_mod_syserr_fail_str(rb_mWaitReadable, n, arg);
14040 }
14041 break;
14042 default:
14043 rb_bug("invalid read/write type passed to rb_readwrite_sys_fail: %d", waiting);
14044 }
14045 rb_exc_raise(rb_class_new_instance(1, &arg, c));
14046}
14047
14048static VALUE
14049get_LAST_READ_LINE(ID _x, VALUE *_y)
14050{
14051 return rb_lastline_get();
14052}
14053
14054static void
14055set_LAST_READ_LINE(VALUE val, ID _x, VALUE *_y)
14056{
14057 rb_lastline_set(val);
14058}
14059
14060/*
14061 * Document-class: IOError
14062 *
14063 * Raised when an IO operation fails.
14064 *
14065 * File.open("/etc/hosts") {|f| f << "example"}
14066 * #=> IOError: not opened for writing
14067 *
14068 * File.open("/etc/hosts") {|f| f.close; f.read }
14069 * #=> IOError: closed stream
14070 *
14071 * Note that some IO failures raise <code>SystemCallError</code>s
14072 * and these are not subclasses of IOError:
14073 *
14074 * File.open("does/not/exist")
14075 * #=> Errno::ENOENT: No such file or directory - does/not/exist
14076 */
14077
14078/*
14079 * Document-class: EOFError
14080 *
14081 * Raised by some IO operations when reaching the end of file. Many IO
14082 * methods exist in two forms,
14083 *
14084 * one that returns +nil+ when the end of file is reached, the other
14085 * raises +EOFError+.
14086 *
14087 * +EOFError+ is a subclass of +IOError+.
14088 *
14089 * file = File.open("/etc/hosts")
14090 * file.read
14091 * file.gets #=> nil
14092 * file.readline #=> EOFError: end of file reached
14093 * file.close
14094 */
14095
14096/*
14097 * Document-class: ARGF
14098 *
14099 * +ARGF+ is a stream designed for use in scripts that process files given as
14100 * command-line arguments or passed in via STDIN.
14101 *
14102 * The arguments passed to your script are stored in the +ARGV+ Array, one
14103 * argument per element. +ARGF+ assumes that any arguments that aren't
14104 * filenames have been removed from +ARGV+. For example:
14105 *
14106 * $ ruby argf.rb --verbose file1 file2
14107 *
14108 * ARGV #=> ["--verbose", "file1", "file2"]
14109 * option = ARGV.shift #=> "--verbose"
14110 * ARGV #=> ["file1", "file2"]
14111 *
14112 * You can now use +ARGF+ to work with a concatenation of each of these named
14113 * files. For instance, +ARGF.read+ will return the contents of _file1_
14114 * followed by the contents of _file2_.
14115 *
14116 * After a file in +ARGV+ has been read +ARGF+ removes it from the Array.
14117 * Thus, after all files have been read +ARGV+ will be empty.
14118 *
14119 * You can manipulate +ARGV+ yourself to control what +ARGF+ operates on. If
14120 * you remove a file from +ARGV+, it is ignored by +ARGF+; if you add files to
14121 * +ARGV+, they are treated as if they were named on the command line. For
14122 * example:
14123 *
14124 * ARGV.replace ["file1"]
14125 * ARGF.readlines # Returns the contents of file1 as an Array
14126 * ARGV #=> []
14127 * ARGV.replace ["file2", "file3"]
14128 * ARGF.read # Returns the contents of file2 and file3
14129 *
14130 * If +ARGV+ is empty, +ARGF+ acts as if it contained STDIN, i.e. the data
14131 * piped to your script. For example:
14132 *
14133 * $ echo "glark" | ruby -e 'p ARGF.read'
14134 * "glark\n"
14135 */
14136
14137/*
14138 * An instance of class \IO (commonly called a _stream_)
14139 * represents an input/output stream in the underlying operating system.
14140 * \Class \IO is the basis for input and output in Ruby.
14141 *
14142 * \Class File is the only class in the Ruby core that is a subclass of \IO.
14143 * Some classes in the Ruby standard library are also subclasses of \IO;
14144 * these include TCPSocket and UDPSocket.
14145 *
14146 * The global constant ARGF (also accessible as <tt>$<</tt>)
14147 * provides an IO-like stream that allows access to all file paths
14148 * found in ARGV (or found in STDIN if ARGV is empty).
14149 * Note that ARGF is not itself a subclass of \IO.
14150 *
14151 * Important objects based on \IO include:
14152 *
14153 * - $stdin.
14154 * - $stdout.
14155 * - $stderr.
14156 * - Instances of class File.
14157 *
14158 * An instance of \IO may be created using:
14159 *
14160 * - IO.new: returns a new \IO object for the given integer file descriptor.
14161 * - IO.open: passes a new \IO object to the given block.
14162 * - IO.popen: returns a new \IO object that is connected to the $stdin and $stdout
14163 * of a newly-launched subprocess.
14164 * - Kernel#open: Returns a new \IO object connected to a given source:
14165 * stream, file, or subprocess.
14166 *
14167 * An \IO stream has:
14168 *
14169 * - A read/write mode, which may be read-only, write-only, or read/write;
14170 * see {Read/Write Mode}[rdoc-ref:IO@Read-2FWrite+Mode].
14171 * - A data mode, which may be text-only or binary;
14172 * see {Data Mode}[rdoc-ref:IO@Data+Mode].
14173 * - A position, which determines where in the stream the next
14174 * read or write is to occur;
14175 * see {Position}[rdoc-ref:IO@Position].
14176 * - A line number, which is a special, line-oriented, "position"
14177 * (different from the position mentioned above);
14178 * see {Line Number}[rdoc-ref:IO@Line+Number].
14179 * - Internal and external encodings;
14180 * see {Encodings}[rdoc-ref:IO@Encodings].
14181 *
14182 * == Extension <tt>io/console</tt>
14183 *
14184 * Extension <tt>io/console</tt> provides numerous methods
14185 * for interacting with the console;
14186 * requiring it adds numerous methods to class \IO.
14187 *
14188 * == Example Files
14189 *
14190 * Many examples here use these filenames and their corresponding files:
14191 *
14192 * - <tt>t.txt</tt>: A text-only file that is assumed to exist via:
14193 *
14194 * text = <<~EOT
14195 * First line
14196 * Second line
14197 *
14198 * Fourth line
14199 * Fifth line
14200 * EOT
14201 * File.write('t.txt', text)
14202 *
14203 * - <tt>t.dat</tt>: A data file that is assumed to exist via:
14204 *
14205 * data = "\u9990\u9991\u9992\u9993\u9994"
14206 * f = File.open('t.dat', 'wb:UTF-16')
14207 * f.write(data)
14208 * f.close
14209 *
14210 * - <tt>t.rus</tt>: A Russian-language text file that is assumed to exist via:
14211 *
14212 * File.write('t.rus', "\u{442 435 441 442}")
14213 *
14214 * - <tt>t.tmp</tt>: A file that is assumed _not_ to exist.
14215 *
14216 * == Modes
14217 *
14218 * A number of \IO method calls must or may specify a _mode_ for the stream;
14219 * the mode determines how stream is to be accessible, including:
14220 *
14221 * - Whether the stream is to be read-only, write-only, or read-write.
14222 * - Whether the stream is positioned at its beginning or its end.
14223 * - Whether the stream treats data as text-only or binary.
14224 * - The external and internal encodings.
14225 *
14226 * === Read/Write Mode
14227 *
14228 * ==== Read/Write Mode Specified as an \Integer
14229 *
14230 * When +mode+ is an integer it must be one or more (combined by bitwise OR (<tt>|</tt>)
14231 * of the following modes:
14232 *
14233 * - +File::RDONLY+: Open for reading only.
14234 * - +File::WRONLY+: Open for writing only.
14235 * - +File::RDWR+: Open for reading and writing.
14236 * - +File::APPEND+: Open for appending only.
14237 * - +File::CREAT+: Create file if it does not exist.
14238 * - +File::EXCL+: Raise an exception if +File::CREAT+ is given and the file exists.
14239 *
14240 * Examples:
14241 *
14242 * File.new('t.txt', File::RDONLY)
14243 * File.new('t.tmp', File::RDWR | File::CREAT | File::EXCL)
14244 *
14245 * Note: Method IO#set_encoding does not allow the mode to be specified as an integer.
14246 *
14247 * ==== Read/Write Mode Specified As a \String
14248 *
14249 * When +mode+ is a string it must begin with one of the following:
14250 *
14251 * - <tt>'r'</tt>: Read-only stream, positioned at the beginning;
14252 * the stream cannot be changed to writable.
14253 * - <tt>'w'</tt>: Write-only stream, positioned at the beginning;
14254 * the stream cannot be changed to readable.
14255 * - <tt>'a'</tt>: Write-only stream, positioned at the end;
14256 * every write appends to the end;
14257 * the stream cannot be changed to readable.
14258 * - <tt>'r+'</tt>: Read-write stream, positioned at the beginning.
14259 * - <tt>'w+'</tt>: Read-write stream, positioned at the end.
14260 * - <tt>'a+'</tt>: Read-write stream, positioned at the end.
14261 *
14262 * For a writable file stream (that is, any except read-only),
14263 * the file is truncated to zero if it exists,
14264 * and is created if it does not exist.
14265 *
14266 * Examples:
14267 *
14268 * File.open('t.txt', 'r')
14269 * File.open('t.tmp', 'w')
14270 *
14271 * === Data Mode
14272 *
14273 * Either of the following may be suffixed to any of the string read/write modes above:
14274 *
14275 * - <tt>'t'</tt>: Text data; sets the default external encoding to +Encoding::UTF_8+;
14276 * on Windows, enables conversion between EOL and CRLF.
14277 * - <tt>'b'</tt>: Binary data; sets the default external encoding to +Encoding::ASCII_8BIT+;
14278 * on Windows, suppresses conversion between EOL and CRLF.
14279 *
14280 * If neither is given, the stream defaults to text data.
14281 *
14282 * Examples:
14283 *
14284 * File.open('t.txt', 'rt')
14285 * File.open('t.dat', 'rb')
14286 *
14287 * The following may be suffixed to any writable string mode above:
14288 *
14289 * - <tt>'x'</tt>: Creates the file if it does not exist;
14290 * raises an exception if the file exists.
14291 *
14292 * Example:
14293 *
14294 * File.open('t.tmp', 'wx')
14295 *
14296 * Note that when using integer flags to set the read/write mode, it's not
14297 * possible to also set the binary data mode by adding the File::BINARY flag
14298 * to the bitwise OR combination of integer flags. This is because, as
14299 * documented in File::Constants, the File::BINARY flag only disables line code
14300 * conversion, but does not change the external encoding at all.
14301 *
14302 * == Encodings
14303 *
14304 * Any of the string modes above may specify encodings --
14305 * either external encoding only or both external and internal encodings --
14306 * by appending one or both encoding names, separated by colons:
14307 *
14308 * f = File.new('t.dat', 'rb')
14309 * f.external_encoding # => #<Encoding:ASCII-8BIT>
14310 * f.internal_encoding # => nil
14311 * f = File.new('t.dat', 'rb:UTF-16')
14312 * f.external_encoding # => #<Encoding:UTF-16 (dummy)>
14313 * f.internal_encoding # => nil
14314 * f = File.new('t.dat', 'rb:UTF-16:UTF-16')
14315 * f.external_encoding # => #<Encoding:UTF-16 (dummy)>
14316 * f.internal_encoding # => #<Encoding:UTF-16>
14317 * f.close
14318 *
14319 * The numerous encoding names are available in array Encoding.name_list:
14320 *
14321 * Encoding.name_list.size # => 175
14322 * Encoding.name_list.take(3) # => ["ASCII-8BIT", "UTF-8", "US-ASCII"]
14323 *
14324 * When the external encoding is set,
14325 * strings read are tagged by that encoding
14326 * when reading, and strings written are converted to that
14327 * encoding when writing.
14328 *
14329 * When both external and internal encodings are set,
14330 * strings read are converted from external to internal encoding,
14331 * and strings written are converted from internal to external encoding.
14332 * For further details about transcoding input and output, see Encoding.
14333 *
14334 * If the external encoding is <tt>'BOM|UTF-8'</tt>, <tt>'BOM|UTF-16LE'</tt>
14335 * or <tt>'BOM|UTF16-BE'</tt>, Ruby checks for
14336 * a Unicode BOM in the input document to help determine the encoding. For
14337 * UTF-16 encodings the file open mode must be binary.
14338 * If the BOM is found, it is stripped and the external encoding from the BOM is used.
14339 *
14340 * Note that the BOM-style encoding option is case insensitive,
14341 * so 'bom|utf-8' is also valid.)
14342 *
14343 * == Open Options
14344 *
14345 * A number of \IO methods accept optional keyword arguments
14346 * that determine how a new stream is to be opened:
14347 *
14348 * - +:mode+: Stream mode.
14349 * - +:flags+: \Integer file open flags;
14350 * If +mode+ is also given, the two are bitwise-ORed.
14351 * - +:external_encoding+: External encoding for the stream.
14352 * - +:internal_encoding+: Internal encoding for the stream.
14353 * <tt>'-'</tt> is a synonym for the default internal encoding.
14354 * If the value is +nil+ no conversion occurs.
14355 * - +:encoding+: Specifies external and internal encodings as <tt>'extern:intern'</tt>.
14356 * - +:textmode+: If a truthy value, specifies the mode as text-only, binary otherwise.
14357 * - +:binmode+: If a truthy value, specifies the mode as binary, text-only otherwise.
14358 * - +:autoclose+: If a truthy value, specifies that the +fd+ will close
14359 * when the stream closes; otherwise it remains open.
14360 *
14361 * Also available are the options offered in String#encode,
14362 * which may control conversion between external internal encoding.
14363 *
14364 * == Lines
14365 *
14366 * Some reader methods in \IO are line-oriented;
14367 * such a method reads one or more lines,
14368 * which are separated by an implicit or explicit line separator.
14369 *
14370 * These methods include:
14371 *
14372 * - Kernel#gets
14373 * - Kernel#readline
14374 * - Kernel#readlines
14375 * - IO.foreach
14376 * - IO.readlines
14377 * - IO#each_line
14378 * - IO#gets
14379 * - IO#readline
14380 * - IO#readlines
14381 * - ARGF.each
14382 * - ARGF.gets
14383 * - ARGF.readline
14384 * - ARGF.readlines
14385 *
14386 * Each of these methods returns +nil+ if called when already at end-of-stream,
14387 * except for IO#readline, which raises an exception.
14388 *
14389 * Each of these methods may be called with:
14390 *
14391 * - An optional line separator, +sep+.
14392 * - An optional line-size limit, +limit+.
14393 * - Both +sep+ and +limit+.
14394 *
14395 * === Line Separator
14396 *
14397 * The default line separator is the given by the global variable <tt>$/</tt>,
14398 * whose value is often <tt>"\n"</tt>.
14399 * The line to be read next is all data from the current position
14400 * to the next line separator:
14401 *
14402 * f = File.open('t.txt')
14403 * f.gets # => "First line\n"
14404 * f.gets # => "Second line\n"
14405 * f.gets # => "\n"
14406 * f.gets # => "Fourth line\n"
14407 * f.gets # => "Fifth line\n"
14408 * f.close
14409 *
14410 * You can specify a different line separator:
14411 *
14412 * f = File.new('t.txt')
14413 * f.gets('l') # => "First l"
14414 * f.gets('li') # => "ine\nSecond li"
14415 * f.gets('lin') # => "ne\n\nFourth lin"
14416 * f.gets # => "e\n"
14417 * f.close
14418 *
14419 * There are two special line separators:
14420 *
14421 * - +nil+: The entire stream is read into a single string:
14422 *
14423 * f = File.new('t.txt')
14424 * f.gets(nil) # => "First line\nSecond line\n\nFourth line\nFifth line\n"
14425 * f.close
14426 *
14427 * - <tt>''</tt> (the empty string): The next "paragraph" is read
14428 * (paragraphs being separated by two consecutive line separators):
14429 *
14430 * f = File.new('t.txt')
14431 * f.gets('') # => "First line\nSecond line\n\n"
14432 * f.gets('') # => "Fourth line\nFifth line\n"
14433 * f.close
14434 *
14435 * === Line Limit
14436 *
14437 * The line to be read may be further defined by an optional argument +limit+,
14438 * which specifies that the line may not be (much) longer than the given limit;
14439 * a multi-byte character will not be split, and so a line may be slightly longer
14440 * than the given limit.
14441 *
14442 * If +limit+ is not given, the line is determined only by +sep+.
14443 *
14444 * # Text with 1-byte characters.
14445 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(1) } # => "F"
14446 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(2) } # => "Fi"
14447 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(3) } # => "Fir"
14448 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(4) } # => "Firs"
14449 * # No more than one line.
14450 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(10) } # => "First line"
14451 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(11) } # => "First line\n"
14452 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets(12) } # => "First line\n"
14453 *
14454 * # Text with 2-byte characters, which will not be split.
14455 * File.open('r.rus') {|f| f.gets(1).size } # => 1
14456 * File.open('r.rus') {|f| f.gets(2).size } # => 1
14457 * File.open('r.rus') {|f| f.gets(3).size } # => 2
14458 * File.open('r.rus') {|f| f.gets(4).size } # => 2
14459 *
14460 * === Line Separator and Line Limit
14461 *
14462 * With arguments +sep+ and +limit+ given,
14463 * combines the two behaviors:
14464 *
14465 * - Returns the next line as determined by line separator +sep+.
14466 * - But returns no more bytes than are allowed by the limit.
14467 *
14468 * Example:
14469 *
14470 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets('li', 20) } # => "First li"
14471 * File.open('t.txt') {|f| f.gets('li', 2) } # => "Fi"
14472 *
14473 * === Line Number
14474 *
14475 * A readable \IO stream has a _line_ _number_,
14476 * which is the non-negative integer line number
14477 * in the stream where the next read will occur.
14478 *
14479 * A new stream is initially has line number +0+.
14480 *
14481 * \Method IO#lineno returns the line number.
14482 *
14483 * Reading lines from a stream usually changes its line number:
14484 *
14485 * f = File.open('t.txt', 'r')
14486 * f.lineno # => 0
14487 * f.readline # => "This is line one.\n"
14488 * f.lineno # => 1
14489 * f.readline # => "This is the second line.\n"
14490 * f.lineno # => 2
14491 * f.readline # => "Here's the third line.\n"
14492 * f.lineno # => 3
14493 * f.eof? # => true
14494 * f.close
14495 *
14496 * Iterating over lines in a stream usually changes its line number:
14497 *
14498 * f = File.open('t.txt')
14499 * f.each_line do |line|
14500 * p "position=#{f.pos} eof?=#{f.eof?} line=#{line}"
14501 * end
14502 * f.close
14503 *
14504 * Output:
14505 *
14506 * "position=19 eof?=false line=This is line one.\n"
14507 * "position=45 eof?=false line=This is the second line.\n"
14508 * "position=70 eof?=true line=This is the third line.\n"
14509 *
14510 * === Line Options
14511 *
14512 * A number of \IO methods accept optional keyword arguments
14513 * that determine how lines in a stream are to be treated:
14514 *
14515 * - +:chomp+: If +true+, line separators are omitted; default is +false+.
14516 *
14517 * == What's Here
14518 *
14519 * First, what's elsewhere. \Class \IO:
14520 *
14521 * - Inherits from {class Object}[rdoc-ref:Object@What-27s+Here].
14522 * - Includes {module Enumerable}[rdoc-ref:Enumerable@What-27s+Here],
14523 * which provides dozens of additional methods.
14524 *
14525 * Here, class \IO provides methods that are useful for:
14526 *
14527 * - {Creating}[rdoc-ref:IO@Creating]
14528 * - {Reading}[rdoc-ref:IO@Reading]
14529 * - {Writing}[rdoc-ref:IO@Writing]
14530 * - {Positioning}[rdoc-ref:IO@Positioning]
14531 * - {Iterating}[rdoc-ref:IO@Iterating]
14532 * - {Settings}[rdoc-ref:IO@Settings]
14533 * - {Querying}[rdoc-ref:IO@Querying]
14534 * - {Buffering}[rdoc-ref:IO@Buffering]
14535 * - {Low-Level Access}[rdoc-ref:IO@Low-Level+Access]
14536 * - {Other}[rdoc-ref:IO@Other]
14537 *
14538 * === Creating
14539 *
14540 * - ::new (aliased as ::for_fd): Creates and returns a new \IO object for the given
14541 * integer file descriptor.
14542 * - ::open: Creates a new \IO object.
14543 * - ::pipe: Creates a connected pair of reader and writer \IO objects.
14544 * - ::popen: Creates an \IO object to interact with a subprocess.
14545 * - ::select: Selects which given \IO instances are ready for reading,
14546 * writing, or have pending exceptions.
14547 *
14548 * === Reading
14549 *
14550 * - ::binread: Returns a binary string with all or a subset of bytes
14551 * from the given file.
14552 * - ::read: Returns a string with all or a subset of bytes from the given file.
14553 * - ::readlines: Returns an array of strings, which are the lines from the given file.
14554 * - #getbyte: Returns the next 8-bit byte read from +self+ as an integer.
14555 * - #getc: Returns the next character read from +self+ as a string.
14556 * - #gets: Returns the line read from +self+.
14557 * - #pread: Returns all or the next _n_ bytes read from +self+,
14558 * not updating the receiver's offset.
14559 * - #read: Returns all remaining or the next _n_ bytes read from +self+
14560 * for a given _n_.
14561 * - #read_nonblock: the next _n_ bytes read from +self+ for a given _n_,
14562 * in non-block mode.
14563 * - #readbyte: Returns the next byte read from +self+;
14564 * same as #getbyte, but raises an exception on end-of-file.
14565 * - #readchar: Returns the next character read from +self+;
14566 * same as #getc, but raises an exception on end-of-file.
14567 * - #readline: Returns the next line read from +self+;
14568 * same as #getline, but raises an exception of end-of-file.
14569 * - #readlines: Returns an array of all lines read read from +self+.
14570 * - #readpartial: Returns up to the given number of bytes from +self+.
14571 *
14572 * === Writing
14573 *
14574 * - ::binwrite: Writes the given string to the file at the given filepath,
14575 * in binary mode.
14576 * - ::write: Writes the given string to +self+.
14577 * - #<<: Appends the given string to +self+.
14578 * - #print: Prints last read line or given objects to +self+.
14579 * - #printf: Writes to +self+ based on the given format string and objects.
14580 * - #putc: Writes a character to +self+.
14581 * - #puts: Writes lines to +self+, making sure line ends with a newline.
14582 * - #pwrite: Writes the given string at the given offset,
14583 * not updating the receiver's offset.
14584 * - #write: Writes one or more given strings to +self+.
14585 * - #write_nonblock: Writes one or more given strings to +self+ in non-blocking mode.
14586 *
14587 * === Positioning
14588 *
14589 * - #lineno: Returns the current line number in +self+.
14590 * - #lineno=: Sets the line number is +self+.
14591 * - #pos (aliased as #tell): Returns the current byte offset in +self+.
14592 * - #pos=: Sets the byte offset in +self+.
14593 * - #reopen: Reassociates +self+ with a new or existing \IO stream.
14594 * - #rewind: Positions +self+ to the beginning of input.
14595 * - #seek: Sets the offset for +self+ relative to given position.
14596 *
14597 * === Iterating
14598 *
14599 * - ::foreach: Yields each line of given file to the block.
14600 * - #each (aliased as #each_line): Calls the given block
14601 * with each successive line in +self+.
14602 * - #each_byte: Calls the given block with each successive byte in +self+
14603 * as an integer.
14604 * - #each_char: Calls the given block with each successive character in +self+
14605 * as a string.
14606 * - #each_codepoint: Calls the given block with each successive codepoint in +self+
14607 * as an integer.
14608 *
14609 * === Settings
14610 *
14611 * - #autoclose=: Sets whether +self+ auto-closes.
14612 * - #binmode: Sets +self+ to binary mode.
14613 * - #close: Closes +self+.
14614 * - #close_on_exec=: Sets the close-on-exec flag.
14615 * - #close_read: Closes +self+ for reading.
14616 * - #close_write: Closes +self+ for writing.
14617 * - #set_encoding: Sets the encoding for +self+.
14618 * - #set_encoding_by_bom: Sets the encoding for +self+, based on its
14619 * Unicode byte-order-mark.
14620 * - #sync=: Sets the sync-mode to the given value.
14621 *
14622 * === Querying
14623 *
14624 * - #autoclose?: Returns whether +self+ auto-closes.
14625 * - #binmode?: Returns whether +self+ is in binary mode.
14626 * - #close_on_exec?: Returns the close-on-exec flag for +self+.
14627 * - #closed?: Returns whether +self+ is closed.
14628 * - #eof? (aliased as #eof): Returns whether +self+ is at end-of-file.
14629 * - #external_encoding: Returns the external encoding object for +self+.
14630 * - #fileno (aliased as #to_i): Returns the integer file descriptor for +self+
14631 * - #internal_encoding: Returns the internal encoding object for +self+.
14632 * - #pid: Returns the process ID of a child process associated with +self+,
14633 * if +self+ was created by ::popen.
14634 * - #stat: Returns the File::Stat object containing status information for +self+.
14635 * - #sync: Returns whether +self+ is in sync-mode.
14636 * - #tty? (aliased as #isatty): Returns whether +self+ is a terminal.
14637 *
14638 * === Buffering
14639 *
14640 * - #fdatasync: Immediately writes all buffered data in +self+ to disk.
14641 * - #flush: Flushes any buffered data within +self+ to the underlying
14642 * operating system.
14643 * - #fsync: Immediately writes all buffered data and attributes in +self+ to disk.
14644 * - #ungetbyte: Prepends buffer for +self+ with given integer byte or string.
14645 * - #ungetc: Prepends buffer for +self+ with given string.
14646 *
14647 * === Low-Level Access
14648 *
14649 * - ::sysopen: Opens the file given by its path,
14650 * returning the integer file descriptor.
14651 * - #advise: Announces the intention to access data from +self+ in a specific way.
14652 * - #fcntl: Passes a low-level command to the file specified
14653 * by the given file descriptor.
14654 * - #ioctl: Passes a low-level command to the device specified
14655 * by the given file descriptor.
14656 * - #sysread: Returns up to the next _n_ bytes read from self using a low-level read.
14657 * - #sysseek: Sets the offset for +self+.
14658 * - #syswrite: Writes the given string to +self+ using a low-level write.
14659 *
14660 * === Other
14661 *
14662 * - ::copy_stream: Copies data from a source to a destination,
14663 * each of which is a filepath or an \IO-like object.
14664 * - ::try_convert: Returns a new \IO object resulting from converting
14665 * the given object.
14666 * - #inspect: Returns the string representation of +self+.
14667 *
14668 */
14669
14670void
14671Init_IO(void)
14672{
14673 VALUE rb_cARGF;
14674#ifdef __CYGWIN__
14675#include <sys/cygwin.h>
14676 static struct __cygwin_perfile pf[] =
14677 {
14678 {"", O_RDONLY | O_BINARY},
14679 {"", O_WRONLY | O_BINARY},
14680 {"", O_RDWR | O_BINARY},
14681 {"", O_APPEND | O_BINARY},
14682 {NULL, 0}
14683 };
14684 cygwin_internal(CW_PERFILE, pf);
14685#endif
14686
14687 rb_eIOError = rb_define_class("IOError", rb_eStandardError);
14688 rb_eEOFError = rb_define_class("EOFError", rb_eIOError);
14689
14690 id_write = rb_intern_const("write");
14691 id_read = rb_intern_const("read");
14692 id_getc = rb_intern_const("getc");
14693 id_flush = rb_intern_const("flush");
14694 id_readpartial = rb_intern_const("readpartial");
14695 id_set_encoding = rb_intern_const("set_encoding");
14696 id_fileno = rb_intern_const("fileno");
14697
14698 rb_define_global_function("syscall", rb_f_syscall, -1);
14699
14700 rb_define_global_function("open", rb_f_open, -1);
14701 rb_define_global_function("printf", rb_f_printf, -1);
14702 rb_define_global_function("print", rb_f_print, -1);
14703 rb_define_global_function("putc", rb_f_putc, 1);
14704 rb_define_global_function("puts", rb_f_puts, -1);
14705 rb_define_global_function("gets", rb_f_gets, -1);
14706 rb_define_global_function("readline", rb_f_readline, -1);
14707 rb_define_global_function("select", rb_f_select, -1);
14708
14709 rb_define_global_function("readlines", rb_f_readlines, -1);
14710
14711 rb_define_global_function("`", rb_f_backquote, 1);
14712
14713 rb_define_global_function("p", rb_f_p, -1);
14714 rb_define_method(rb_mKernel, "display", rb_obj_display, -1);
14715
14716 rb_cIO = rb_define_class("IO", rb_cObject);
14717 rb_include_module(rb_cIO, rb_mEnumerable);
14718
14719 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "READABLE", INT2NUM(RUBY_IO_READABLE));
14720 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "WRITABLE", INT2NUM(RUBY_IO_WRITABLE));
14721 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "PRIORITY", INT2NUM(RUBY_IO_PRIORITY));
14722
14723 /* exception to wait for reading. see IO.select. */
14724 rb_mWaitReadable = rb_define_module_under(rb_cIO, "WaitReadable");
14725 /* exception to wait for writing. see IO.select. */
14726 rb_mWaitWritable = rb_define_module_under(rb_cIO, "WaitWritable");
14727 /* exception to wait for reading by EAGAIN. see IO.select. */
14728 rb_eEAGAINWaitReadable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EAGAINWaitReadable", rb_eEAGAIN);
14729 rb_include_module(rb_eEAGAINWaitReadable, rb_mWaitReadable);
14730 /* exception to wait for writing by EAGAIN. see IO.select. */
14731 rb_eEAGAINWaitWritable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EAGAINWaitWritable", rb_eEAGAIN);
14732 rb_include_module(rb_eEAGAINWaitWritable, rb_mWaitWritable);
14733#if EAGAIN == EWOULDBLOCK
14734 rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable = rb_eEAGAINWaitReadable;
14735 /* same as IO::EAGAINWaitReadable */
14736 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "EWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable", rb_eEAGAINWaitReadable);
14737 rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable = rb_eEAGAINWaitWritable;
14738 /* same as IO::EAGAINWaitWritable */
14739 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "EWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable", rb_eEAGAINWaitWritable);
14740#else
14741 /* exception to wait for reading by EWOULDBLOCK. see IO.select. */
14742 rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable", rb_eEWOULDBLOCK);
14743 rb_include_module(rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitReadable, rb_mWaitReadable);
14744 /* exception to wait for writing by EWOULDBLOCK. see IO.select. */
14745 rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable", rb_eEWOULDBLOCK);
14746 rb_include_module(rb_eEWOULDBLOCKWaitWritable, rb_mWaitWritable);
14747#endif
14748 /* exception to wait for reading by EINPROGRESS. see IO.select. */
14749 rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitReadable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EINPROGRESSWaitReadable", rb_eEINPROGRESS);
14750 rb_include_module(rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitReadable, rb_mWaitReadable);
14751 /* exception to wait for writing by EINPROGRESS. see IO.select. */
14752 rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitWritable = rb_define_class_under(rb_cIO, "EINPROGRESSWaitWritable", rb_eEINPROGRESS);
14753 rb_include_module(rb_eEINPROGRESSWaitWritable, rb_mWaitWritable);
14754
14755#if 0
14756 /* This is necessary only for forcing rdoc handle File::open */
14757 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cFile, "open", rb_io_s_open, -1);
14758#endif
14759
14760 rb_define_alloc_func(rb_cIO, io_alloc);
14761 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "new", rb_io_s_new, -1);
14762 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "open", rb_io_s_open, -1);
14763 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "sysopen", rb_io_s_sysopen, -1);
14764 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "for_fd", rb_io_s_for_fd, -1);
14765 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "popen", rb_io_s_popen, -1);
14766 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "foreach", rb_io_s_foreach, -1);
14767 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "readlines", rb_io_s_readlines, -1);
14768 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "read", rb_io_s_read, -1);
14769 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "binread", rb_io_s_binread, -1);
14770 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "write", rb_io_s_write, -1);
14771 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "binwrite", rb_io_s_binwrite, -1);
14772 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "select", rb_f_select, -1);
14773 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "pipe", rb_io_s_pipe, -1);
14774 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "try_convert", rb_io_s_try_convert, 1);
14775 rb_define_singleton_method(rb_cIO, "copy_stream", rb_io_s_copy_stream, -1);
14776
14777 rb_define_method(rb_cIO, "initialize", rb_io_initialize, -1);
14778
14779 rb_output_fs = Qnil;
14780 rb_define_hooked_variable("$,", &rb_output_fs, 0, deprecated_str_setter);
14781
14782 rb_default_rs = rb_fstring_lit("\n"); /* avoid modifying RS_default */
14783 rb_gc_register_mark_object(rb_default_rs);
14784 rb_rs = rb_default_rs;
14785 rb_output_rs = Qnil;
14786 rb_define_hooked_variable("$/", &rb_rs, 0, deprecated_str_setter);

14842 /* Set I/O position from the beginning */
14843 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "SEEK_SET", INT2FIX(SEEK_SET));
14844 /* Set I/O position from the current position */
14845 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "SEEK_CUR", INT2FIX(SEEK_CUR));
14846 /* Set I/O position from the end */
14847 rb_define_const(rb_cIO, "SEEK_END", INT2FIX(SEEK_END));

14913 /* Holds the original stdout */

14989 argf = rb_class_new_instance(0, 0, rb_cARGF);
14990
14991 rb_define_readonly_variable("$<", &argf);
14992 /*
14993 * ARGF is a stream designed for use in scripts that process files given
14994 * as command-line arguments or passed in via STDIN.
14995 *
14996 * See ARGF (the class) for more details.
14997 */
14998 rb_define_global_const("ARGF", argf);
14999
15000 rb_define_hooked_variable("$.", &argf, argf_lineno_getter, argf_lineno_setter);
15001 rb_define_hooked_variable("$FILENAME", &argf, argf_filename_getter, rb_gvar_readonly_setter);
15002 ARGF.filename = rb_str_new2("-");
15003
15004 rb_define_hooked_variable("$-i", &argf, opt_i_get, opt_i_set);
15005 rb_gvar_ractor_local("$-i");
15006
15007 rb_define_hooked_variable("$*", &argf, argf_argv_getter, rb_gvar_readonly_setter);

15010 atexit(pipe_atexit);
15011#endif
